```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
library(tidyverse)
library(here)
library(janitor)
library(nlstools)
```

```{r}
# Read in the data
fish_catch <- read_csv(here("data", "fish_catch.csv"), skip = 2) %>% 
  drop_na() %>% 
  rownames_to_column() %>% 
  clean_names() %>% 
  mutate(wild_catch = as.numeric(wild_catch),
         year = as.numeric(year))

# Create a vector for rownames
rank <- c(0:62)

rownames(rank) <- fish_catch$rowname
```

```{r}
# Exploratory data viz
ggplot(data = fish_catch, aes(x = year, y = as.numeric(wild_catch))) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(1950, 2012, by = 10))
```

```{r}
# Log transformed data
ggplot(data = fish_catch, aes(x = year, y = log(wild_catch))) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(1950, 2012, by = 10))
```


Wild catches seem to follow a steady increase over the first five decades comprising the data and then reaching a plateau between the 1990s and 2010s.
